keyTakeAways: Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man, was convicted of raping two women in northern Utah in 2008, with a sentence of five years to life in prison.
Rossi allegedly faked his death in 2020 by publishing an obituary claiming he died of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, which led authorities to question his status and initiate a search.
He fled to Scotland and was arrested there after hospital staff recognized his tattoos from an Interpol notice, indicating he had used aliases and evaded capture for years.
Rossi used at least a dozen aliases over the years, including claiming to be an Irish orphan named Arthur Knight, and previously failed to register as a sex offender in Rhode Island.
He was identified via a decade-old DNA rape kit, part of Utah's effort to clear its rape kit backlog.
The victim in the first case described a pattern of financial manipulation, debt collection, and abuse before the rape, and emphasized the need for accountability and safety.
Despite his claims of innocence and arguments for parole, the jury convicted him, and the judge labeled him a 'serial abuser' and 'flight risk'.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A 38-year-old man named Nicholas Rossi, whose legal name is Nicholas Alahverdian, was sentenced to five years to life in prison in Utah after being convicted of first-degree rape in two separate incidents in 2008. Rossi allegedly faked his death in 2020 by claiming he died of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, which led to a decade-long evasion of justice. He used multiple aliases, including claiming to be an Irish orphan named Arthur Knight, and was arrested in Scotland in 2024 after hospital staff recognized his distinctive tattoos from an Interpol notice. Authorities identified him through a decade-old DNA rape kit, part of Utah's effort to clear its rape kit backlog. The victims, both women, testified about financial manipulation and abuse before the crimes. Prosecutors described Rossi as a dangerous flight risk and serial abuser, while he maintained his innocence during sentencing. He is scheduled for a second sentencing in November, following a prior conviction in September.
title: Man accused of faking his own death and fleeing the US after rape charges gets at least five years in prison
